Rather they do not honour the orphan they do not treat him with kindness despite their wealth or it means that they do not give him what is his due from an inheritance

Name: The Dawn
Verse: And urge not on the feeding of the poor.
Tafseer: and they do not urge neither themselves nor others the feeding of the needy;

Name: The Dawn
Verse: And ye devour heritages with devouring greed.
Tafseer: and they devour inheritance turāth means mīrāth greedily lamman that is to say voraciously when they appropriate lammuhum the women’s and the young ones’ share of the inheritance together with their own share of it or to their own wealth;

Name: The Dawn
Verse: And love wealth with abounding love.
Tafseer: and they love wealth with abounding love that is to say greatly and so they do not expend any of it a variant reading in the case of all four verbs has the second person plural.

Name: The Dawn
Verse: Nay, but when the earth is ground to atoms, grinding, grinding,
Tafseer: No indeed! — a deterrent for them from such conduct. When the earth is pulverised repeatedly when it is shaken until every edifice has collapsed and is destroyed

Name: The Dawn
Verse: And thy Lord shall come with angels, rank on rank,
Tafseer: and your Lord that is to say His command and the angels arrive rank on rank saffan saffan is a circumstantial qualifier meaning ‘standing in rows’ or ‘made up of many ranks’

Name: The Dawn
Verse: And hell is brought near that day; on that day man will remember, but how will the remembrance (then avail him) ?
Tafseer: and Hell on that day is brought near pulled by seventy thousand sets of reins each set of reins pulled by the hands of seventy thousand angels as it groans and seethes in fury; on that day yawma’idhin is a substitution for idhā ‘when’ the response to which is the following man that is to say the disbeliever will remember his prodigal conduct in it but how will remembering avail him now? the interrogative is meant as a denial in other words his remembering that will not be of any use to him.

Name: The Dawn
Verse: He will say: Ah, would that I had sent before me (some provision) for my life!
Tafseer: He will say as he remembers ‘O yā is for calling attention to something would that I had sent ahead good deeds and faith for my life!’ for a good life in the Hereafter or it means ‘during my life’ in the world.

Name: The Dawn
Verse: None punisheth as He will punish on that day!
Tafseer: Then on that day none shall mete out read yu‘adhdhibu His God’s chastisement that is to say He shall not delegate it to any other;

Name: The Dawn
Verse: None bindeth as He then will bind.
Tafseer: and likewise none shall bind read yūthiqu His bind a variant reading has yu‘adhdhabu ‘none shall be chastised’ and yūthaqu ‘none shall be bound’ so that the suffixed pronoun of ‘adhābahu and wathāqahu refers to the chastisement and the binds of the disbeliever the meaning then being ‘none shall be chastised as he shall and none shall be bound as he shall be bound’.

Name: The Dawn
Verse: But ah! thou soul at peace!
Tafseer: ‘O soul at peace! the one secure namely the believing one.

Name: The Dawn
Verse: Return unto thy Lord, content in His good pleasure!
Tafseer: Return — this is said to it upon death — to your Lord that is to say return to His command and to His will pleased with the reward pleasing in God’s sight with your deeds; in other words return O soul combining both descriptions both of which are circumstantial qualifiers. And it will be said to it at the Resurrection

Name: The Dawn
Verse: Enter thou among My bondmen!
Tafseer: Then enter among My righteous servants!

Name: The Dawn
Verse: Enter thou My Garden!
Tafseer: And enter My Paradise!’ with them.

Name: The City
Verse: Nay, I swear by this city -
Tafseer: I swear lā is extra by this land of Mecca

Name: The City
Verse: And thou art an indweller of this city -
Tafseer: and you O Muhammad (s) have free disposal of sanction for this land in that you will be given permission to fight in it — and indeed God fulfilled this promise to him on the day of the Conquest of Mecca thus this is a parenthetical statement intervening between that by which the oath has been sworn and that which is a supplement thereto.

Name: The City
Verse: And the begetter and that which he begat,
Tafseer: And by the begetter that is Adam and that which he begat that is his descendants mā ‘that which’ actually means man ‘whom’.

Name: The City
Verse: We verily have created man in an atmosphere:
Tafseer: We certainly created man al-insān the generic noun in travail in a state of toil and hardship struggling with the tribulations of this world and the calamities of the Hereafter.

Name: The City
Verse: Thinketh he that none hath power over him ?
Tafseer: Does he suppose does the strong man of Quraysh namely Abū’l-Ashadd b. Kalada presume on account of his strength that an softened in place of the hardened form its subject omitted that is to say annahu no one will have power over him? Yet God has power over him.

Name: The City
Verse: And he saith: I have destroyed vast wealth:
Tafseer: He says ‘I have exhausted in enmity of Muhammad (s) vast wealth!’ great wealth piles and piles of it.

Name: The City
Verse: Thinketh he that none beholdeth him ?
Tafseer: Does he suppose that an in other words annahu no one has seen him? with regard to what he has expended to know the quantity thereof; God knows the quantity thereof; but it is not in reality that much so as to be considered a great amount and in any case He will requite him for his evil conduct.

Name: The City
Verse: Did We not assign unto him two eyes
Tafseer: Have We not given an interrogative meant as an affirmative in other words ‘We have certainly given’ him two eyes

Name: The City
Verse: And a tongue and two lips,
Tafseer: and a tongue and two lips

Name: The City
Verse: And guide him to the parting of the mountain ways ?
Tafseer: and guided him to the two paths? did We not point out to him the path of good and that of evil?

Name: The City
Verse: But he hath not attempted the Ascent -
Tafseer: Yet why does he not assault the obstacle? why does he not surmount it?

Name: The City
Verse: Ah, what will convey unto thee what the Ascent is! -
Tafseer: And what will show you what will make known to you what the obstacle is? that he is to surmount — intended to emphasise its enormity this statement is a parenthetical one. He explains the way to surmount it by saying

Name: The City
Verse: (It is) to free a slave,
Tafseer: the freeing of a slave from bondage

Name: The City
Verse: And to feed in the day of hunger.
Tafseer: or to give food on a day of hunger

Name: The City
Verse: An orphan near of kin,
Tafseer: to an orphan near of kin maqraba means qarāba

Name: The City
Verse: Or some poor wretch in misery,
Tafseer: or a needy person in misery matraba literally means ‘clinging to the dust turāb’ because of his poverty; a variant reading has two verbal nouns in place of the two verbs fakka ‘he freed’ and at‘ama ‘he fed’ the first being in a genitive construction fakku raqabatin ‘the freeing of a slave’ and the second with nunation it‘āmun ‘to give food’ in which case there is an implied iqtihāmu before al-‘aqaba of which the said reading becomes the explication;

Name: The City
Verse: And to be of those who believe and exhort one another to perseverance and exhort one another to pity.
Tafseer: while being thumma kāna is a supplement to iqtahama ‘he assaulted’; thumma is for the ordering of things to be mentioned in other words what is meant is that at the point of the assault he was one of those who believe and enjoin one another to steadfastness in pursuing obedience and in refraining from disobedience and enjoin one another to compassion marhama means rahma towards creatures.

Name: The City
Verse: Their place will be on the right hand.
Tafseer: Those the ones described by the said attributes are the ones of the right side al-maymana means al-yamīn.

Name: The City
Verse: But those who disbelieve Our revelations, their place will be on the left hand.
Tafseer: But those who disbelieve in Our signs they are the ones of the left side al-mash’ama means al-shimāl.

Name: The City
Verse: Fire will be an awning over them.
Tafseer: Over them will be an enclosing Fire read mu’sada or mūsada closed on top of them.

Name: The Sun
Verse: By the sun and his brightness,
Tafseer: By the sun and her morning light

Name: The Sun
Verse: And the moon when she followeth him,
Tafseer: and by the moon when it follows her rising after she has set

Name: The Sun
Verse: And the day when it revealeth him,
Tafseer: and by the day when it reveals her as it rises high

Name: The Sun
Verse: And the night when it enshroudeth him,
Tafseer: and by the night when it enshrouds her covering her up with its darkness idhā ‘when’ in all three instances is an absolute adverbial operated by the verbal action of the oath.

Name: The Sun
Verse: And the heaven and Him Who built it,
Tafseer: By the heaven and the One Who built it

Name: The Sun
Verse: And the earth and Him Who spread it,
Tafseer: and by the earth and the One Who spread it laid out flat.

Name: The Sun
Verse: And a soul and Him Who perfected it
Tafseer: and by the soul that is to say by all souls and the One Who proportioned it in its created form mā in all three instances relates to the verbal action or functions as man ‘the one who’

Name: The Sun
Verse: And inspired it (with conscience of) what is wrong for it and (what is) right for it.
Tafseer: and inspired to discern its vices and piety He pointed out to it the path of good and that of evil the placing of taqwā ‘piety’ second takes into account the rhyme endings of the verses; the response to the oath is the following

Name: The Sun
Verse: He is indeed successful who causeth it to grow,
Tafseer: Successful indeed qad the lām of laqad ‘indeed’ has been omitted from it for the sake of brevity will be the one who purifies it purges it of sins

Name: The Sun
Verse: And he is indeed a failure who stunteth it.
Tafseer: and he will indeed have failed he who eclipses it he who obscures it with acts of disobedience dassāhā is actually dassasahā but the second sīn has been replaced with an alif for phonetic ease.

Name: The Sun
Verse: (The tribe of) Thamud denied (the truth) in their rebellious pride,
Tafseer: Thamūd denied their messenger Sālih because of their rebellious nature

Name: The Sun
Verse: When the basest of them broke forth
Tafseer: when the most wretched of them whose name was Qudār was dispatched when he hastened in order to hamstring the she-camel with their approval.

Name: The Sun
Verse: And the messenger of Allah said: It is the she-camel of Allah, so let her drink!
Tafseer: But then the messenger of God Sālih said to them ‘This is the she-camel of God so let her have her drink!’ her drink on her day — one day was hers the next theirs.

Name: The Sun
Verse: But they denied him, and they hamstrung her, so Allah doomed them for their sin and rased (their dwellings).
Tafseer: But they denied him with regard to his saying this as being a command from God — which if they contravened would immediately result in chastisement being sent down on them — then hamstrung her they slew it in order to appropriate her share of the drinking water. So their Lord closed in on them the chastisement because of their sin and meted it equally among them that is the closing in on them in other words He subsumed them all by it so that not one of them escaped.

Name: The Sun
Verse: He dreadeth not the sequel (of events).
Tafseer: And He does not read wa-lā or fa-lā fear the consequence of it.

Name: The Night
Verse: By the night enshrouding
Tafseer: By the night as it enshrouds with its darkness all that is between the heaven and the earth

Name: The Night
Verse: And the day resplendent
Tafseer: and by the day as it unveils as it is revealed and becomes manifest idhā ‘as’ in both instances is an absolute adverbial operated by the verbal action of the oath

Name: The Night
Verse: And Him Who hath created male and female,
Tafseer: and by the One Who mā either functions as man ‘the One Who’ or it is related to a verbal action created the male and the female Adam and Eve or every male and female — the hermaphrodite although problematic for us is in fact either male or female according to God and therefore a person actually commits perjury if he speaks with one thinking that because he has sworn not to speak with a male or a female; he may do so with a hermaphrodite.

Name: The Night
Verse: Lo! your effort is dispersed (toward divers ends).
Tafseer: Assuredly your efforts your deeds are dissimilar with some working towards Paradise by means of obedience while others in effect are working towards the Fire through acts of disobedience.

Name: The Night
Verse: As for him who giveth and is dutiful (toward Allah)
Tafseer: As for him who gives what is due to God and is fearful of God

Name: The Night
Verse: And believeth in goodness;
Tafseer: and affirms the truth of the best word that is the truth of ‘there is no god but God’ in both places here and below verse 9

Name: The Night
Verse: Surely We will ease his way unto the state of ease.
Tafseer: We shall surely ease his way to the abode of ease to Paradise.

Name: The Night
Verse: But as for him who hoardeth and deemeth himself independent,
Tafseer: But as for him who is niggardly with what is due to God and deems himself self-sufficient without need for His reward 929 and denies the best word

Name: The Night
Verse: And disbelieveth in goodness;
Tafseer: and denies the best word

Name: The Night
Verse: Surely We will ease his way unto adversity.
Tafseer: We shall surely ease his way We shall pave for him the way to hardship to the Fire;

Name: The Night
Verse: His riches will not save him when he perisheth.
Tafseer: And his wealth shall not mā is or negation avail him when he perishes in the Fire.

Name: The Night
Verse: Lo! Ours it is (to give) the guidance
Tafseer: Truly with Us lies all guidance the pointing out of the path of guidance from that of error so that Our command may be followed by adhering to the former manner of conduct and that Our prohibition may also be heeded by refraining from falling into the latter manner of conduct.

Name: The Night
Verse: And lo! unto Us belong the latter portion and the former.
Tafseer: And truly to Us belong the Hereafter and the first life that is to say that of this world and so whoever seeks either of the two from anyone other than Us has erred.

Name: The Night
Verse: Therefor have I warned you of the flaming Fire
Tafseer: So I have warned you of I have threatened you O people of Mecca with a raging fire talazzā ‘raging’ one of the two original tā’ letters of tatalazzā has been omitted; a variant reading retains it tatalazzā that is ‘one that is flaming’

Name: The Night
Verse: Which only the most wretched must endure,
Tafseer: which none shall enter but the wretched one al-ashqā means al-shaqī

Name: The Night
Verse: He who denieth and turneth away.
Tafseer: he who denies the Prophet and turns away from faith — this delimiting of those who deserve to enter this fire constitutes an interpretation of His saying But He forgives other than that to whomever He will Q. 448 which in turn suggests that what is meant is that entry into the Fire which will be everlasting.

Name: The Night
Verse: Far removed from it will be the righteous
Tafseer: The God-fearing one al-atqā means al-taqī shall be spared it he will be removed far away from it

Name: The Night
Verse: Who giveth his wealth that he may grow (in goodness).
Tafseer: he who gives his wealth to purify himself offering it as a means of self purification before God exalted be He by making this payment for the sake of God exalted be He and not for show or the sake of reputation so that he or the offering stands purified in the sight of God. This verse was revealed regarding the truthful one al-siddīq Abū Bakr may God be pleased with him when he purchased Bilāl the Ethiopian who was being tortured on account of his faith and then freed him whereat the disbelievers said ‘He only did this in return for a favour which he must have owed him’ and so the following was revealed

Name: The Night
Verse: And none hath with him any favour for reward,
Tafseer: and no one has any favour outstanding with him that must be requited;

Name: The Night
Verse: Except as seeking (to fulfil) the purpose of his Lord Most High.
Tafseer: but he did this only seeking the pleasure of his Lord the Most High that is to say only seeking to secure God’s reward;

Name: The Night
Verse: He verily will be content.
Tafseer: and verily soon he shall himself be pleased with the reward he will be given in Paradise. The verse applies equally to anyone who may do as he Abū Bakr did may God be pleased with him and such a person will thereby be removed far from the Fire and rewarded.

Name: The Morning Hours
Verse: By the morning hours
Tafseer: By the forenoon that is to say the first part of the day or all of it

Name: The Morning Hours
Verse: And by the night when it is stillest,
Tafseer: and by the night when it is still — or sajā can mean ‘when it envelops all in its darkness’.

Name: The Morning Hours
Verse: Thy Lord hath not forsaken thee nor doth He hate thee,
Tafseer: Your Lord has neither forsaken you He has not abandoned you O Muhammad (s) nor does He hate you this was revealed when after the revelation had not come to him for fifteen days the disbelievers said ‘His Lord has parted with him and hates him’.

Name: The Morning Hours
Verse: And verily the latter portion will be better for thee than the former,
Tafseer: And verily the Hereafter shall be better for you by virtue of the honours awaiting you thereat than the first life this world.

Name: The Morning Hours
Verse: And verily thy Lord will give unto thee so that thou wilt be content.
Tafseer: And verily your Lord shall give you in the Hereafter of good things a bounteous gift and you shall be satisfied with it — and so the Prophet s said ‘In that case I shall not be satisfied if a single person from among my community remains in the Fire’ the response to the oath terminates here with two affirmations and two negations.

Name: The Morning Hours
Verse: Did He not find thee an orphan and protect (thee) ?
Tafseer: Did He not find you an orphan an interrogative meant as an affirmative in other words He did indeed find you an orphan having lost your father before you were born or shortly thereafter and shelter you? by having your uncle Abū Tālib embrace you as part of his household.

Name: The Morning Hours
Verse: Did He not find thee wandering and direct (thee) ?
Tafseer: And did He not find you erring from the revealed Law which you now follow and guided you? that is and then guided you to it.

Name: The Morning Hours
Verse: Did He not find thee destitute and enrich (thee) ?
Tafseer: And did He not find you needy poor and enrich you? and made you content with the spoils and other things which He gave you — in a hadīth it is stated ‘Wealth comes not from the proliferation of transient worldly goods but wealth comes from the contentedness of the soul’.

Name: The Morning Hours
Verse: Therefor the orphan oppress not,
Tafseer: So as for the orphan do not oppress him by appropriating his wealth or otherwise

Name: The Morning Hours
Verse: Therefor the beggar drive not away,
Tafseer: and as for the beggar do not drive him away do not repel him on account of his poverty

Name: The Morning Hours
Verse: Therefor of the bounty of thy Lord be thy discourse.
Tafseer: and as for your Lord’s grace to you by way of prophethood and otherwise proclaim it make it known. The omission in certain instances of the suffixed pronoun referring to the Prophet s from the end of the verbs is intended to sustain the end-rhyme of the verses.

Name: Solace
Verse: Have We not caused thy bosom to dilate,
Tafseer: Did We not expand an interrogative meant as an affirmative in other words ‘We did indeed expand’ your breast for you O Muhammad (s) by means of prophethood and otherwise

Name: Solace
Verse: And eased thee of the burden
Tafseer: and relieve you of your burden

Name: Solace
Verse: Which weighed down thy back;
Tafseer: that which weighed down your back? — this is similar to where God says that God may forgive you what is past of your sin Q. 482.

Name: Solace
Verse: And exalted thy fame ?
Tafseer: Did We not exalt your mention? For you are mentioned where I God am mentioned in the call announcing the time for prayer adhān in the second call to perform the prayer iqāma in the witnessing ‘there is no god but God Muhammad is His Messenger’ tashahhud in the Friday sermon and in other instances.

Name: Solace
Verse: But lo! with hardship goeth ease,
Tafseer: For truly with hardship comes ease.

Name: Solace
Verse: Lo! with hardship goeth ease;
Tafseer: Truly with hardship comes ease the Prophet s suffered much hardship at the hands of the disbelievers but then he enjoyed ease when he was assisted to victory by God over them.

Name: Solace
Verse: So when thou art relieved, still toil
Tafseer: So when you are finished from performing prayer toil exert yourself in supplication to God

Name: Solace
Verse: And strive to please thy Lord.
Tafseer: and seek devote yourself humbly to your Lord.

Name: The Fig
Verse: By the fig and the olive,
Tafseer: By the fig and the olive that is the two edible foods — or these denote the names of two mountains in Syria on which these two foods grow —

Name: The Fig
Verse: By Mount Sinai,
Tafseer: and by the Mount Sinai the mountain on which God exalted be He spoke to Moses sīnīn means ‘the one blessed’ or ‘the fair one with fruitful trees’

Name: The Fig
Verse: And by this land made safe;
Tafseer: and by this secure land Mecca as people were secure in it in the time of pagandom and are still secure in it in Islam.

Name: The Fig
Verse: Surely We created man of the best stature
Tafseer: Verily We created man al-insān the generic in the best of forms in the best proportioning of his shape.

Name: The Fig
Verse: Then we reduced him to the lowest of the low,
Tafseer: Then in the case of certain individuals of his species We reduced him to the lowest of the low — a metaphor for old age and weakness at which point a believer’s deeds are fewer than when he was young; but he will still have his reward as God exalted be He says

Name: The Fig
Verse: Save those who believe and do good works, and theirs is a reward unfailing.
Tafseer: except those who believe and perform righteous deeds for they shall have an unfailing reward one unending — in a hadīth it is stated ‘When a believer reaches that stage of old age which prevents him from performing good deeds then what he used to do is recorded in his favour instead’.

Name: The Fig
Verse: So who henceforth will give the lie to thee about the judgment ?
Tafseer: So what makes you deny O disbeliever thereafter — after the mention of man being created in the best of forms and his being reduced to the vilest of age all of which indicates the power of God to resurrect — the Judgement? the Requital that will be preceded by the Resurrection and the Reckoning. In other words what makes you disbelieve in all this? Nothing does!

Name: The Fig
Verse: Is not Allah the most conclusive of all judges ?
Tafseer: Is not God the fairest of all judges? the most just of all judges. His passing judgement by means of the process of requital is one such example. In a hadīth it is stated ‘Whoever recites sūrat wa’l-tīni ‘By the fig’ to the end of it let him then say “Yes Indeed! And I am of those who bear witness to this!” ’

Name: The Clot
Verse: Read: In the name of thy Lord Who createth,
Tafseer: Recite bring recitation into existence beginning with In the Name of your Lord Who created all creatures;

Name: The Clot
Verse: Createth man from a clot.
Tafseer: created man al-insān the generic from a blood-clot ‘alaq is the plural of ‘alaqa which is a small quantity of congealing blood.

Name: The Clot
Verse: Read: And thy Lord is the Most Bounteous,
Tafseer: Recite reiterating the first one and your Lord is the Most Generous having no counterpart in terms of His generosity wa-rabbuka’l-akram is a circumstantial qualifier referring to the subject of the verb iqra’ ‘recite’

Name: The Clot
Verse: Who teacheth by the pen,
Tafseer: Who taught the art of script by the pen — the first to write with it was the prophet Enoch Idrīs peace be upon him —

Name: The Clot
Verse: Teacheth man that which he knew not.
Tafseer: taught man al-insān the generic what he did not know before he was taught in the way of guidance the art of writing crafts and so on.

Name: The Clot
Verse: Nay, but verily man is rebellious
Tafseer: Nay but verily man is wont to be rebellious

Name: The Clot
Verse: That he thinketh himself independent!
Tafseer: when he sees it that is to say his own soul to be self-sufficient in terms of wealth — this was revealed regarding Abū Jahl ra’ā ‘sees’ means to see mentally; istaghnā ‘self-sufficient’ is the second direct object; an ra’āhu ‘when he sees it’ is an object denoting reason.

Name: The Clot
Verse: Lo! unto thy Lord is the return.
Tafseer: Surely to your Lord O man is the return — meant as a threat for him — and so He will requite the rebellious one with what he deserves.

Name: The Clot
Verse: Hast thou seen him who dissuadeth
Tafseer: Have you seen a-ra’ayta in all three instances here and below is an exclamation of wonder him namely Abū Jahl who forbids

Name: The Clot
Verse: A slave when he prayeth ?
Tafseer: a servant namely Muhammad (s) when he prays?

Name: The Clot
Verse: Hast thou seen if he relieth on the guidance (of Allah)
Tafseer: Have you considered what if he the one forbidden should be upon a path of guidance

Name: The Clot
Verse: Or enjoineth piety ?
Tafseer: or aw is for division be bidding others to fear of God?

Name: The Clot
Verse: Hast thou seen if he denieth (Allah’s guidance) and is froward ?
Tafseer: Have you considered what if he the one forbidding the Prophet should be denying God’s guidance and turning away? from faith.

Name: The Clot
Verse: Is he then unaware that Allah seeth ?
Tafseer: Is he not aware that God sees? what has issued from him that is to say He does indeed know it and will requite him for it. In other words ‘Marvel O you being addressed at the way in which he forbids prayer and at the fact that the one being forbidden is actually the one upon guidance bidding to fear of God while the one forbidding is a denier disregarding faith’.

Name: The Clot
Verse: Nay, but if he cease not We will seize him by the forelock -
Tafseer: No indeed! — a repudiation of him — Assuredly if la-in the lām is for oaths he does not desist from the disbelief that he is upon We shall seize him by the forelock We shall drag him to the Fire by his forelock

Name: The Clot
Verse: The lying, sinful forelock -
Tafseer: a lying iniquitous forelock! nāsiyatin an indefinite noun substituting for a definite — the description of this forelock in such terms is meant figuratively and what is actually meant is that individual.

Name: The Clot
Verse: Then let him call upon his henchmen!
Tafseer: Let him then call upon the henchmen of his council the members of his council nādin — a place of assembly where people gather to talk. He Abū Jahl had said to the Prophet s in reproof having forbidden him from prayer ‘You are well aware that there is none in this town who has recourse to as large a council of men as I do. Verily I shall fill this entire valley with mature steeds and young men in battle against you if you so wish!’

Name: The Clot
Verse: We will call the guards of hell.
Tafseer: We shall call the Zabāniya the grim stern angels to destroy him as stated in the hadīth ‘Had he called his council of henchmen together the Zabāniya would have seized him right before his own eyes!’.

Name: The Clot
Verse: Nay, Obey not thou him. But prostrate thyself, and draw near (unto Allah).
Tafseer: No indeed! — a repudiation of him — Do not obey him O Muhammad (s) and abandon prayer and prostrate yourself perform prayer to God and draw near to Him through obedience to Him.

Name: Power
Verse: Lo! We revealed it on the Night of Predestination.
Tafseer: Lo! We revealed it that is the Qur’ān in its entirety sending it down from the Preserved Tablet to the heaven of this world on the Night of Ordainment that is the Night of great eminence.

Name: Power
Verse: Ah, what will convey unto thee what the Night of Power is!
Tafseer: And what will show you what will make known to you O Muhammad (s) what the Night of Ordainment is? — intended to emphasise its great status and to provoke marvel at it.

Name: Power
Verse: The Night of Power is better than a thousand months.
Tafseer: The Night of Ordainment is better than a thousand months in which there is no Night of Ordainment for a righteous deed on that Night is better than one performed for a thousand months without it.

Name: Power
Verse: The angels and the Spirit descend therein, by the permission of their Lord, with all decrees.
Tafseer: The angels and the Spirit namely Gabriel descend tanazzalu one of the two original tā’ letters of tatanazzalu has been omitted in it on that night by the leave of their Lord by His command with every command that God has decreed from that year to the following one min is causative functioning as bi ‘with’.

Name: Power
Verse: (The night is) Peace until the rising of the dawn.
Tafseer: It is peaceful salāmun hiya a predicate preceding the subject until the rising of the dawn read matla‘ or matli‘ until the time it rises it is peaceful because of the numerous salutations of peace salām spoken in it by the angels who every time they come across a believing man or believing woman bid him peace.

Name: The Clear Proof
Verse: Those who disbelieve among the People of the Scripture and the idolaters could not have left off (erring) till the clear proof came unto them,
Tafseer: The disbelievers from among min explicative the People of the Scripture and the idolaters that is the idol-worshippers wa’l-mushrikīna is a supplement to ahl ‘the People of’ were not going to leave off munfakkīna is the predicate of yakun ‘were’ that is to say they were not going to abandon their ways until the clear proof namely Muhammad (s) should come to them that is until it came to them;

Name: The Clear Proof
Verse: A messenger from Allah, reading purified pages
Tafseer: a messenger from God rasūlun mina’Llāhi substitutes for al-bayyinatu ‘the clear proof’ namely the Prophet s reciting pages purified of all falsehood

Name: The Clear Proof
Verse: Containing correct scriptures.
Tafseer: wherein are upright precepts written rulings that are upright that is to say one who recites what contains all that and that is the Qur’ān. Thus some of them believed in it while others disbelieved.

Name: The Clear Proof
Verse: Nor were the People of the Scripture divided until after the clear proof came unto them.
Tafseer: And those who were given the Scripture did not become divided regarding belief in him the Prophet s except after the clear proof had come to them namely the Prophet s — or the Qur’ān which he brought as his miracle. Before his s arrival they had all agreed to believe in him when he would come; then those who disbelieved in him from among them became envious of him.

Name: The Clear Proof
Verse: And they are ordered naught else than to serve Allah, keeping religion pure for Him, as men by nature upright, and to establish worship and to pay the poor-due. That is true religion.
Tafseer: And they were only commanded in their Scripture the Torah and the Gospel to worship God illā li-ya‘budū means illā an ya‘budū an having been omitted and the lām added devoting religion purely to Him free of any idolatry as hanīfs upright in following the religion of Abraham and the religion of Muhammad (s) when he would come — so how is it that they disbelieved in him? and to establish prayer and pay the alms. That is the upright religion the upright creed.

Name: The Clear Proof
Verse: Lo! those who disbelieve, among the People of the Scripture and the idolaters, will abide in fire of hell. They are the worst of created beings.
Tafseer: Truly the disbelievers from among the People of the Scripture and the idolaters shall be in the fire of Hell to abide therein khālidīna an implied circumstantial qualifier in other words it will be decreed for them by God exalted be He to abide therein — those are the worst of creatures.

Name: The Clear Proof
Verse: (And) lo! those who believe and do good works are the best of created beings.
Tafseer: Truly those who believe and perform righteous deeds — they are the best of creatures al-bariyya means al-khalīqa.

Name: The Clear Proof
Verse: Their reward is with their Lord: Gardens of Eden underneath which rivers flow, wherein they dwell for ever. Allah hath pleasure in them and they have pleasure in Him. This is (in store) for him who feareth his Lord.
Tafseer: Their reward with their Lord will be Gardens of Eden as a residence underneath which rivers flow wherein they shall abide forever. God is pleased with them because of their obedience of Him and they are pleased with Him because of His reward. That is the reward for him who fears his Lord for him who fears His punishment and hence desists from disobeying Him exalted be He.

Name: The Earthquake
Verse: When Earth is shaken with her (final) earthquake
Tafseer: When earth is shaken when it is rocked for the rising of the Hour with its final quake with its most violent rocking one that befits its magnitude

Name: The Earthquake
Verse: And Earth yieldeth up her burdens,
Tafseer: and the earth brings forth its burdens its hidden treasures and its dead casting them onto its surface

Name: The Earthquake
Verse: And man saith: What aileth her ?
Tafseer: and man the disbeliever in resurrection says ‘What is wrong with it?’ — in denial of that situation.

Name: The Earthquake
Verse: That day she will relate her chronicles,
Tafseer: On that day yawma’idhin substitutes for and is the response to idhā ‘when’ it shall relate its chronicles it shall inform of the good and evil deeds committed in it

Name: The Earthquake
Verse: Because thy Lord inspireth her.
Tafseer: for its Lord will have inspired it that is He will have commanded her to do this — in a hadīth it is stated ‘It the earth shall testify to every single deed committed by every servant and handmaiden upon its surface’.

Name: The Earthquake
Verse: That day mankind will issue forth in scattered groups to be shown their deeds.
Tafseer: On that day mankind shall issue forth they will depart from the site of the Reckoning in separate groups divided up so that those taking it their book by the right hand will go to Paradise while those taking it by the left hand will go to the Fire to be shown their deeds that is the requital for them in either Paradise or the Fire.

Name: The Earthquake
Verse: And whoso doeth good an atom’s weight will see it then,
Tafseer: So whoever does an atom’s weight of good shall see it he shall see its reward

Name: The Earthquake
Verse: And whoso doeth ill an atom’s weight will see it then.
Tafseer: and whoever does an atom’s weight of evil shall see it he shall see its requital.

Name: The Coursers
Verse: By the snorting courses,
Tafseer: By the chargers the steeds that charge in attack and snort with a snorting — this being the name of the sound which they emit from inside them when they charge;

Name: The Coursers
Verse: Striking sparks of fire
Tafseer: by the strikers the steeds that strike fire by way of sparks with their hoofs when they gallop across rocky terrain by night;

Name: The Coursers
Verse: And scouring to the raid at dawn,
Tafseer: by the dawn-raiders the steeds that make raids against the enemy at dawn at the hands of their riders

Name: The Coursers
Verse: Then, therewith, with their trail of dust,
Tafseer: raising stirring up therein in the place of their charge or at that time of dawn a trail of dust by the power of their movement

Name: The Coursers
Verse: Cleaving, as one, the centre (of the foe),
Tafseer: cleaving therewith with the dust a host of the enemy that is to say cutting right into their centre! the verb is supplemented to the noun in the above instances because it serves to explain the verbal action in other words wa’llātī ‘adawna fa-awrayna fa-agharna ‘by those that charge then strike sparks then raid’.

Name: The Coursers
Verse: Lo! man is an ingrate unto his Lord
Tafseer: Verily man the disbeliever is ungrateful to his Lord thankless denying the reality of His graces exalted be He

Name: The Coursers
Verse: And lo! he is a witness unto that;
Tafseer: and verily to that ingratitude of his he is a witness bearing witness against himself to his own actions.

Name: The Coursers
Verse: And lo! in the love of wealth he is violent.
Tafseer: And verily in the love of wealth he is avid and is therefore niggardly with it.

Name: The Coursers
Verse: Knoweth he not that, when the contents of the graves are poured forth
Tafseer: Does he not know that when that which is in the graves in the way of the dead is strewn when it is turned over and brought out that is to say that when they are raised

Name: The Coursers
Verse: And the secrets of the breasts are made known,
Tafseer: and that which is in the breasts the hearts of disbelief or faith is obtained when it is revealed and examined

Name: The Coursers
Verse: On that day will their Lord be perfectly informed concerning them.
Tafseer: on that day their Lord will indeed be Aware of them Knower of them and will requite them for their disbelief the pronoun reverts to the plural because of the collective import of the term ‘man’; this sentence indicates the direct object of the verb ya‘lamu ‘does he not know’ that is to say ‘We will requite him at the time mentioned’; khabīrun ‘Aware’ is semantically connected to yawma’idhin ‘on that day’ even though in fact God is ever Aware because that is the Day of Requital.

Name: The Calamity
Verse: The Calamity!
Tafseer: The Clattering Blow the Resurrection that will make hearts clatter by its terrors.

Name: The Calamity
Verse: What is the Calamity ?
Tafseer: What is the Clattering Blow? — intended to emphasise its awesomeness mā’l-qāri‘a both of these elements constitute a subject and a predicate and together the predicate of the first al-qāri‘a.

Name: The Calamity
Verse: Ah, what will convey unto thee what the Calamity is!
Tafseer: And what will show you what will make known to you what the Clattering Blow is? — additional emphasis of its awesomeness the first mā is a subject and what follows it is its predicate; the second mā and its predicate also function together as the second direct object of the verb adrā ‘show’.

Name: The Calamity
Verse: A day wherein mankind will be as thickly-scattered moths
Tafseer: The day yawma that which renders it accusative is the verb indicated by al-qāri‘a in other words by the implied taqra‘u ‘it clatters’ mankind will be like scattered moths like a throng of scattered locusts surging into each other in confusion until they are summoned to the Reckoning

Name: The Calamity
Verse: And the mountains will become as carded wool.
Tafseer: and the mountains will be like tufts of wool like carded wool in terms of the lightness with which it floats in the air until it comes to settle upon the earth.

Name: The Calamity
Verse: Then, as for him whose scales are heavy (with good works),
Tafseer: Then as for him whose scales weigh heavy in that his good deeds outweigh his misdeeds

Name: The Calamity
Verse: He will live a pleasant life.
Tafseer: he will enjoy a pleasant life in Paradise that is to say a pleasing one for he will be pleased with it that is it will be pleasing to him;

Name: The Calamity
Verse: But as for him whose scales are light,
Tafseer: but as for him whose scales weigh light in that his evil deeds outweigh his good ones

Name: The Calamity
Verse: A bereft and Hungry One will be his mother,
Tafseer: his home will be the Abyss.

Name: The Calamity
Verse: Ah, what will convey unto thee what she is! -
Tafseer: And what will show you what it is? that is to say what the Abyss is.

Name: The Calamity
Verse: Raging Fire.
Tafseer: It is A scorching fire of extremely hot temperature the hā’ of hiya is for consonantal quiescence and is retained when reciting without a subsequent pause or with; some omit it when reciting without a pause.

Name: Rivalry in Worldly Increase
Verse: Rivalry in worldly increase distracteth you
Tafseer: Rivalry in worldly things mutual vainglory about wealth children and men distracts you preoccupies you diverting you from obedience to God

Name: Rivalry in Worldly Increase
Verse: Until ye come to the graves.
Tafseer: until you visit the graves either in that you have died and then been buried in them or it means to the extent that you actually count the dead as a something to rival one another by.

Name: Rivalry in Worldly Increase
Verse: Nay, but ye will come to know!
Tafseer: No indeed! — a disavowal. You will come to know!

Name: Rivalry in Worldly Increase
Verse: Nay, but ye will come to know!
Tafseer: Again no indeed! You will come to know the evil consequences of your mutual vainglory at the moment of the extraction of the soul then you will come to know in the grave.

Name: Rivalry in Worldly Increase
Verse: Nay, would that ye knew (now) with a sure knowledge!
Tafseer: No indeed! — verily — Were you to know with certain knowledge the consequences of your vainglory you would not preoccupy yourselves with it for

Name: Rivalry in Worldly Increase
Verse: For ye will behold hell-fire.
Tafseer: you would surely see hell-fire the Fire la-tarawunna’l-jahīma this is the response to an omitted oath; the third consonant of the root of the verb r-’-y together with the second have been omitted and its vowel has been transposed onto the rā’.

Name: Rivalry in Worldly Increase
Verse: Aye, ye will behold it with sure vision.
Tafseer: Again you will surely see it — repeated for emphasis — with the eye of certainty ‘ayna is a verbal noun as both ra’ā and ‘āyana have the same meaning.

Name: Rivalry in Worldly Increase
Verse: Then, on that day, ye will be asked concerning pleasure.
Tafseer: Then on that day the day you see it you will assuredly be questioned la-tus’alunna the nūn of the indicative has been omitted because of one nūn coming after the other; likewise omitted is the wāw indicating the plural person of the verb because of two unvocalised consonants coming together about the comforts of the world the health leisure security food drink and other things which one enjoys in this world.

Name: The Declining Day
Verse: By the declining day,
Tafseer: By Time! — or it ‘asr can mean the period from the declining of the sun to sunset or it may denote the afternoon prayer.

Name: The Declining Day
Verse: Lo! man is a state of loss,
Tafseer: Verily man al-insān the generic is in a state of loss in all his bargaining

Name: The Declining Day
Verse: Save those who believe and do good works, and exhort one another to truth and exhort one another to endurance.
Tafseer: except those who believe and perform righteous deeds they are not in a state of loss and enjoin one another to follow the truth faith and enjoin one another to patience in maintaining obedience and in refraining from acts of disobedience.

Name: The Traducer
Verse: Woe unto every slandering traducer,
Tafseer: Woe waylun an expression implying chastisement to every backbiter who is a slanderer frequently engaging in backbiting and slander that is to say defamation — this was revealed regarding those who slandered the Prophet s and the believers the likes of Umayya b. Khalaf al-Walīd b. al-Mughīra and others —

Name: The Traducer
Verse: Who hath gathered wealth (of this world) and arranged it.
Tafseer: who amasses read jama‘a or jamma‘a wealth and counts it over keeping count of it and stores it aside as a provision against the unforeseeable calamities of time.

Name: The Traducer
Verse: He thinketh that his wealth will render him immortal.
Tafseer: He thinks in his ignorance that his wealth will make him immortal never to die.

Name: The Traducer
Verse: Nay, but verily he will be flung to the Consuming One.
Tafseer: Nay! — a repudiation — He will surely be flung la-yunbadhanna is the response to an omitted oath that is he will be hurled down into the Crusher that crushes everything that is thrown into it.

Name: The Traducer
Verse: Ah, what will convey unto thee what the Consuming One is!
Tafseer: And what will show you what will make known to you what the Crusher is?

Name: The Traducer
Verse: (It is) the fire of Allah, kindled,
Tafseer: It is the fire of God kindled set ablaze

Name: The Traducer
Verse: Which leapeth up over the hearts (of men).
Tafseer: which peers over the hearts to burn them — the pain of which is much more severe than any other because of the delicate nature of the heart.

Name: The Traducer
Verse: Lo! it is closed in on them
Tafseer: Lo! it will be closed in mu’sada or mūsada on them ‘alayhim ‘on them’ the plural pronoun takes into account the plural import of kull ‘every’

Name: The Traducer
Verse: In outstretched columns.
Tafseer: in outstretched mumaddadatin is an adjective qualifying the preceding noun ‘amadin columns read ‘umudin or ‘amadin and will therefore be inside the columns.

Name: The Elephant
Verse: Hast thou not seen how thy Lord dealt with the owners of the Elephant ?
Tafseer: Have you not considered an interrogative meant to provoke marvel in other words ‘marvel at’ the way in which your Lord dealt with the Men of the Elephant? who was named Mahmūd and the men were Abraha King of Yemen and his troops. He had built a church in San‘ā’ in order to divert pilgrims away from Mecca to it. A man from among the Banū Kināna defecated in it and stained its prayer niche with a deflowered virgin’s blood in contempt of it. Abraha then swore that he would knock down the Ka‘ba. So he approached Mecca with his troops riding Yemeni elephants with Mahmūd at the vanguard. But when they turned to destroy the Ka‘ba God unleashed upon them what He relates in His words

Name: The Elephant
Verse: Did He not bring their stratagem to naught,
Tafseer: Did He not make — that is to say He did indeed make — their stratagem to destroy the Ka‘ba go astray ending up in failure and destruction

Name: The Elephant
Verse: And send against them swarms of flying creatures,
Tafseer: and unleashed upon them swarms of birds birds in droves one following the next it is said there is no singular form for it abābīl like asātīr; but some say that the singular is abūl or ibāl or ibbīl similar in constructed pattern to ‘ajūl miftāh and sikkīn

Name: The Elephant
Verse: Which pelted them with stones of baked clay,
Tafseer: pelting them with stones of baked clay

Name: The Elephant
Verse: And made them like green crops devoured (by cattle) ?
Tafseer: thus making them like devoured blades? like the leaves of crops which have been consumed trampled and destroyed by animals. God destroyed each one of them with his own stone inscribed with his name larger than a lentil in size but smaller than a chick-pea able to pierce through an egg a man or an elephant and go through the ground. This took place in the year of the Prophet’s birth s.

Name: Winter or Qureysh
Verse: For the taming of Qureysh.
Tafseer: In gratitude for the security of Quraysh

Name: Winter or Qureysh
Verse: For their taming (We cause) the caravans to set forth in winter and summer.
Tafseer: their security īlāfihim repeated for emphasis; it is a verbal noun from the verb ālafa for the journey of winter to Yemen and the journey of summer to Syria every year they made use of these two journeys to provide for their trade at the station of Abraham in Mecca in order to attend to the House of God which was their source of pride; they Quraysh were the descendants of al-Nadr b. Kināna;

Name: Winter or Qureysh
Verse: So let them worship the Lord of this House,
Tafseer: let them worship fa’l-ya‘budū is semantically connected to li-ilāfi ‘for the security’ the fā’ being extra the Lord of this House

Name: Winter or Qureysh
Verse: Who hath fed them against hunger and hath made them safe from fear.
Tafseer: Who has fed them against that is on account of hunger and made them secure from that is on account of fear they used to suffer hunger in Mecca due to the lack of crops and they feared the army of the Elephant.

Name: Small Kindnesses
Verse: Hast thou observed him who belieth religion ?
Tafseer: Have you seen him who denies the Judgement? the Requital and the Reckoning that is to say ‘Do you know who he is?’ If you do not know him then

Name: Small Kindnesses
Verse: That is he who repelleth the orphan,
Tafseer: That is he read an implied huwa after the fā’ of fa-dhālika who repels the orphan that is to say who violently drives him away from what is his due

Name: Small Kindnesses
Verse: And urgeth not the feeding of the needy.
Tafseer: and does not urge either himself or others to the feeding of the needy this was revealed regarding al-‘Āsī b. Wā’il or al-Walīd b. al-Mughīra.

Name: Small Kindnesses
Verse: Ah, woe unto worshippers
Tafseer: So woe to them who pray

Name: Small Kindnesses
Verse: Who are heedless of their prayer;
Tafseer: those who are heedless of their prayers neglectful delaying them from their appointed times

Name: Small Kindnesses
Verse: Who would be seen (at worship)
Tafseer: those who make a pretence with prayers and otherwise

Name: Small Kindnesses
Verse: Yet refuse small kindnesses!
Tafseer: and deny aid as insignificant as a needle a hatchet a cooking pot or a bowl.

Name: Abundance
Verse: Lo! We have given thee Abundance;
Tafseer: We have assuredly given you O Muhammad (s) Abundance — the name of a river in Paradise and his the Prophet’s pool around which his community shall gather; al-kawthar also means the abundant good that has been given to the Prophet such as prophethood the Qur’ān intercession and the like.

Name: Abundance
Verse: So pray unto thy Lord, and sacrifice.
Tafseer: So pray to your Lord the prayer of the Festival of Immolation ‘īd al-nahr and sacrifice your offering.

Name: Abundance
Verse: Lo! it is thy insulter (and not thou) who is without posterity.
Tafseer: Indeed it is your antagonist your hater who is the severed one refraining from all acts of good or the one whose line of offspring will be severed by his not having any this was revealed regarding al-‘Āsī b. Wā’il who called the Prophet s al-abtar ‘the severed one’ when his son al-Qāsim died.

Name: The Disbelievers
Verse: Say: O disbelievers!
Tafseer: Say ‘O disbelievers!

Name: The Disbelievers
Verse: I worship not that which ye worship;
Tafseer: I do not worship at present what you worship of idols

Name: The Disbelievers
Verse: Nor worship ye that which I worship.
Tafseer: and you do not worship at present what I worship and that is God exalted be He alone

Name: The Disbelievers
Verse: And I shall not worship that which ye worship.
Tafseer: nor will I worship in the future what you have worshipped

Name: The Disbelievers
Verse: Nor will ye worship that which I worship.
Tafseer: nor will you worship in the future what I worship God knew that they would never become believers the use of the inanimate mā ‘what’ to refer to God is meant to counter the reference to ‘what thing’ they worship.

Name: The Disbelievers
Verse: Unto you your religion, and unto me my religion.
Tafseer: You have your religion idolatry and I have a religion’ Islam this was revealed before he was commanded to wage war against the idolaters all seven Qur’ānic readers omit the yā’ of the genitive possessive construction in wa-liya dīni whether with a pause or without; Ya‘qūb however retains it in both cases.

Name: Succour
Verse: When Allah’s succour and the triumph cometh
Tafseer: When the help of God for His Prophet s against his enemies comes together with victory the victory over Mecca

Name: Succour
Verse: And thou seest mankind entering the religion of Allah in troops,
Tafseer: and you see people entering God’s religion that is to say Islam in throngs in large droves after they had been entering one by one — this was after the conquest of Mecca when the Arabs from all corners of the land came to him willingly in obedience to his command —

Name: Succour
Verse: Then hymn the praises of thy Lord, and seek forgiveness of Him. Lo! He is ever ready to show mercy.
Tafseer: then glorify with praise of your Lord that is continuously praising Him and seek forgiveness from Him; for verily He is ever ready to relent. The Prophet s after this sūra had been revealed would frequently repeat the words subhāna’Llāhi wa bi-hamdihi ‘Glory and praise be to God’ and astaghfiru’Llāha wa-atūbu ilayhi ‘I seek forgiveness from God and I repent to Him’; with the revelation of this final sūra he realised that his end was near. The victory over Mecca was in Ramadān of year 8; the Prophet s passed away in Rabī‘ I of the year 10.

Name: Palm Fibre
Verse: The power of Abu Lahab will perish, and he will perish.
Tafseer: Perish ruined be the hands of Abū Lahab in other words all of him — the use of ‘hands’ here to denote all of him is figurative and is because most actions are performed by them; the statement is an invocation — and perish he! may he be ruined! this tabba is a predicate as where one says ahlakahu’Llāhu wa-qad halak ‘God destroyed him and he indeed is destroyed’. When the Prophet threatened him with the chastisement he said ‘If what my brother’s son says is true then I shall ransom myself from it with my wealth and sons!’; so the following was revealed

Name: Palm Fibre
Verse: His wealth and gains will not exempt him.
Tafseer: His wealth will not avail him nor what he has earned wa-kasab means wa-kasbihi that is to say his sons; mā aghnā means mā yughnī.

Name: Palm Fibre
Verse: He will be plunged in flaming Fire,
Tafseer: He will soon enter a Fire of flames that is to say a fire that is flaming and ignited this statement is the source of his nickname which was given to him on account of his flaming reddish fair face

Name: Palm Fibre
Verse: And his wife, the wood-carrier,
Tafseer: and his wife wa’mra’atuhu is a supplement to the person of the verb yaslā ‘he will enter’ separated by the clause of the direct object and its qualification — and this was Umm Jamīl — the carrier read hammālatu or hammālata of firewood cactus and thorns which she used to fling into the path of the Prophet s.

Name: Palm Fibre
Verse: Will have upon her neck a halter of palm-fibre.
Tafseer: with a rope of palm-fibre around her neck fī jīdihā hablun min masadin is a circumstantial qualifier referring to hammālata’l-hatab which in turn is either a description of imra’atahu ‘his wife’ or the predicate of an implied subject.

Name: The Unity
Verse: Say: He is Allah, the One!
Tafseer: Say ‘He is God One Allāhu is the predicate of huwa ‘He is’ and ahadun is its substitution or a second predicate.

Name: The Unity
Verse: Allah, the eternally Besought of all!
Tafseer: God the Self-Sufficient Besought of all Allāhu’l-samad constitute a subject and a predicate al-samad means the One Who is always sought at times of need

Name: The Unity
Verse: He begetteth not nor was begotten.
Tafseer: He neither begot for no likeness of Him can exist nor was begotten since createdness is precluded in His case.

Name: The Unity
Verse: And there is none comparable unto Him.
Tafseer: Nor is there anyone equal to Him’ neither match nor comparison lahu ‘to Him’ is semantically connected to kufuwan ‘equal’ but precedes it because it is the object of the intended negation; ahadun ‘anyone’ which is the subject of yakun ‘is there’ has been placed after the predicate of the latter kufuwan ‘equal’ in order to retain the harmony of the end-rhyme of the verses.

Name: The Daybreak
Verse: Say: I seek refuge in the Lord of the Daybreak
Tafseer: Say ‘I seek refuge in the Lord of the Daybreak the morning

Name: The Daybreak
Verse: From the evil of that which He created;
Tafseer: from the evil of what He has created of obligated animate beings and non-obligated ones and from all inanimates such as poison and so on;

Name: The Daybreak
Verse: From the evil of the darkness when it is intense,
Tafseer: and from the evil of darkness when it gathers that is from night when it becomes dark and the moon when it is absent

Name: The Daybreak
Verse: And from the evil of malignant witchcraft,
Tafseer: and from the evil of the women-blowers sorceresses who blow on knots which they knot into strings blowing into them certain words but without spittle; however al-Zamakhsharī says ‘with this spittle’ — sorceresses such as the daughters of the said Labīd —

Name: The Daybreak
Verse: And from the evil of the envier when he envieth.
Tafseer: and from the evil of an envier when he envies’ when he manifests his envy and behaves in accordance with it — such as the mentioned Labīd from among the Jews who were envious of the Prophet s; the mention of these three elements of evil which are already subsumed by the statement ‘of what He has created’ is because of the severity of their evil.

Name: Mankind
Verse: Say: I seek refuge in the Lord of mankind,
Tafseer: Say ‘I seek refuge in the Lord of mankind their Creator and their Possessor they mankind have been singled out for mention here in order to honour them and a preface to seeking refuge from the evil of the one who whispers in their hearts;

Name: Mankind
Verse: The King of mankind,
Tafseer: the King of mankind

Name: Mankind
Verse: The God of mankind,
Tafseer: the God of mankind both maliki’l-nās and ilāhi’l-nās are either substitutions or adjectival qualifications or explicative supplements; the repetition of the annexed word al-nās is meant as an additional explication

Name: Mankind
Verse: From the evil of the sneaking whisperer,
Tafseer: from the evil of the slinking whisperer Satan — he is referred to by the name of the action waswasa on account of his repeated engaging in it — who slinks away and recoils from the heart whenever God is mentioned

Name: Mankind
Verse: Who whispereth in the hearts of mankind,
Tafseer: who whispers in the breasts of mankind in their hearts — whenever they neglect to remember God

Name: Mankind
Verse: Of the jinn and of mankind.
Tafseer: of the jinn and mankind’ mina’l-jinnati wa’l-nāsi an explication for the whispering Satan being of the jinn and also of the humans similar to God’s saying the devils of humans and jinn Q. 6112; or mina’l-jinnati ‘of the jinn’ is an explication for him Satan wa’l-nāsi ‘and of mankind’ being a supplement to al-waswās ‘the whisperer’. Both explanations apply to the evil of the mentioned Labīd and his daughters; the objection to the first opinion is that humans do not ‘whisper’ in the hearts of other humans but that it is the jinn who whisper in their hearts I would respond by saying that human beings also ‘whisper’ in a manner appropriate to them beginning externally whereafter their whispers reach the heart and establish themselves in it in the way in which this customarily happens. But God knows best what is correct and to Him shall be the return and the final destination and may God bless our Master Muhammad and his family and Companions and grant them all much peace forever and always. God suffices for us and what an excellent guardian is He! And there is no power or might except in God the Sublime the Tremendous.
